Description: Almost complete glazed composition New Year's flask, of lentoid shape; upper part missing and neck battered; broad collar consisting of several concentric registers of geometric design (tear drops and rectangle) around the neck; band of V-shaped pattern (chevron pattern) encircling edges; figures arranged symmetrically on the sides of the neck, difficult to identify as the faience is very worn off, likely ibex (probably not seated baboon); in dense and fine white paste; no glaze remaining.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Marked '4' in pencil, a reference to the number of the object in the EEF distribution list.

This New Year’s flask is recorded on the EEF distribution list for Boston as an 'aryballos, nearly complete, with necklace' from Naukratis. Much better preserved than any other specimens recovered from the site, it is also made in a different paste, whitish in colour. It does not seem to have been produced locally, unlike the ' “pilgrim-bottles” of fine yellow paste’ that Petrie mentioned in his publication (Petrie 1886, 37). New Year’s flasks are very common during the 26th dynasty. When cartouches are incised on the body of the flasks, they always refers to pharaohs of the 26th dynasty, especially Apries and Amasis, or to the Divine Votaress Ankhnesneferibre (God’s wife of Amun from around 586 to 525 BC) (Caubet and Pierrat-Bonnefois 2005, 148-151, no. 398). Specimens discovered outside of Egypt seem to originate from 7th-6th century contexts (Caubet and Pierrat-Bonnefois 2005, 151). However, recent excavations provided a few examples from later contexts. They are attested in late 26th-early 27th dynasty contexts (Masson 2007, 614, pl. XXVII) and in Persian contexts at ‘Ayn Manawir in the Oasis of Dakhla (Wuttmann et al. 1996, 429- 430). These flasks, offered as a gift for the New Year, were possibly meant to contain the water of the Nile as it rose at the beginning of the flood season. Caubet, A. and Pierrat-Bonnefois, G. 2005, Faïences de l’Antiquité. De l’Égypte à l’Iran, Catalogue de l’exposition du Musée du Louvre 10 juin-12 septembre 2005, Paris. Masson, A. 2007, ‘Le quartier des prêtres du temple de Karnak: rapport préliminaire de la fouille de la maison VII, 2001-2003’, Cahiers de Karnak XII. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Wuttmann M. et al. 1996, ‘Premier rapport préliminaire des travaux sur le site de ‘Ayn Manawir (oasis de Kharga)’, Bulletin de l’institut français d’archéologie orientale 96. On the evolution of the profile and decoration of the New Year’s flasks: Blanquet, C.-H. 1992, ‘Typologie de la bouteille du Nouvel An’, Amosiadès, Mélanges offerts au Professeur Claude Vandersleyen, Louvain. Clerc, G., Karageorghis, V., Lagarce, E. and Leclant, J. 1976, Fouilles de Kition. II. Objets égyptiens et égyptisants: scarabées, amulettes et figurines en pâte de verre et en faïence, vase plastique en faïence. Sites I et II, 1959-1975, Nicosie, 242-243.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (FA.11) (phase 2)
